title: What are some examples of redundancy and repetition in writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Redundancies I find often while editing: The nape of his neck itched. (Where else does a person have a nape?)The wrist of his forearm. (Right, that wrist. Not the one on his leg.)The palm of his hand. (His palm is adequate, unless you’re talking about trees.)He nodded his head. (What else would he nod?)When rowing with oars, keep a steady rhythm. (You only row with oars. If they are paddles, you’re paddling.)Surrounded on all sides by forest. (Surrounded means on all sides.)The evening sunset. (What, it’s different from the morning sunset?)Saute the stir-fry vegetables. (Well, it’s better than boiling them.)Careless writers use repetitions too often. I highlight repetitions and suggest the writer use synonyms to eliminate repetitions because over-use of repetitions can be distracting in a sentence or paragraph. However, if you use repetitions judiciously for emphasis, such use is often ignored. Sorry, couldn’t resist.

Here are a few examples of redundancy: He nodded his head in agreement. (What else would he have nodded?)We were surrounded by farmland on all sides. (That’s what “surrounded” means.)She squinted her eyes to see better. (You can’t squint anything else.)She drove up in an orange-colored Beetle. (As opposed to an orange-flavored Beetle?)
